organization.fullName: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

identificationModule.briefTitle: Inositol to Reduce Retinopathy of Prematurity

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Severe retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is associated with adverse outcomes, but relationships between milder ROP and outcomes have not been well defined. This study hypothesized that children with ROP stage ≤3 who did not receive ophthalmologic intervention would have worse motor, cognitive, and language skills and more vision abnormalities than children without ROP. The study found that children with milder forms of ROP did not have adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes at 2 years’ corrected age compared to children without ROP, though they did exhibit an increased incidence of strabismus.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
This investigation was a secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effects of myo-inositol on ROP in the NICHD Neonatal Research Network. The study aimed to address the knowledge gap regarding the relationship between ROP that regresses without intervention and neurodevelopment in early childhood.

The study population consisted of 506 children born extremely preterm (<28 weeks’ gestation) evaluated at 22-26 months’ corrected age. Participants were categorized into three groups: 1) children with no history of ROP, 2) children with history of ROP stage ≤3 without ophthalmologic intervention, and 3) children with history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention (retinal ablation, scleral buckling, vitrectomy, or anti-VEGF therapy).

Primary outcomes were assessed using the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development, 3rd Edition (Bayley-III) composite scores for motor, cognitive, and language skills. Secondary outcomes included behavioral difficulties assessed by the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) and ophthalmologic measures such as strabismus, nystagmus, roving eye movements, tracking ability, and visual acuity history.

Statistical analyses utilized adjusted linear or modified Poisson models, adjusting for baseline covariates including maternal race, gestational age, sex, and severe IVH. Results showed no difference in Bayley-III scores between children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention and those without ROP. However, children requiring intervention had significantly lower composite scores and worse visual acuity. The study concludes that while mild ROP is not associated with general neurodevelopmental impairment at 2 years, ophthalmologic follow-up is necessary due to increased risks of strabismus.

armGroups.label: Children with no history of ROP (group 1)
armGroups.description: Children with no history of Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP).

armGroups.label: Children with history of ROP stage ≤3 without ophthalmologic intervention (group 2)
armGroups.description: Children with history of ROP stage ≤3 who did not receive ophthalmologic intervention.

armGroups.label: Children with history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention (group 3)
armGroups.description: Children with history of ROP who received ophthalmologic intervention. Ophthalmologic intervention for ROP included retinal ablation, scleral buckling, vitrectomy, or anti-VEGF therapy.

interventions.name: Retinal ablation
interventions.description: Ophthalmologic intervention for ROP (e.g., laser photocoagulation).
armGroupLabels: Children with history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention (group 3)

interventions.name: Scleral buckling
armGroupLabels: Children with history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention (group 3)

interventions.name: Vitrectomy
armGroupLabels: Children with history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention (group 3)

interventions.name: Anti-VEGF therapy
interventions.description: Ophthalmologic intervention for ROP involving anti-vascular endothelial growth factor administration.
armGroupLabels: Children with history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention (group 3)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development, 3rd Edition (Bayley-III) composite scores
primaryOutcomes.description: Composite motor, cognitive, and language scores. Mean score of 100 and a standard deviation (SD) of 15. Children untestable due to severe developmental delay were assigned a cognitive score of 54, composite language score of 46, and composite motor score of 46.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Behavioral difficulties assessed using T-scores for syndrome scales, problem scales (internalizing, externalizing, and total), and DSM-oriented scales. T-scores <65 classified as normal, 65-69 as borderline, and ≥70 classified as clinically significant.

Outcomes assessed by medical history and neurological examination, including assessment for strabismus, nystagmus, roving eye movements, ability to track 180 degrees, eye surgery for non-ROP indication, and prescription of corrective lenses.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) level
secondaryOutcomes.description: Classification of cerebral palsy (CP) severity: no or mild CP refers to level ≤1, moderate CP refers to levels 2 or 3, and severe CP refers to levels 4 or 5.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Diagnosis or suspicion of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:
* Born extremely preterm (<28 weeks’ gestation)
* Cared for in hospitals of the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Neonatal Research Network
* Born between April 2014-September 2015
* Survived at least 12 hours for trial enrollment

Exclusion Criteria:
* Major congenital anomalies or syndromes known to potentially affect development
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: Children born extremely preterm (<28 weeks’ gestation) and cared for in hospitals of the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Neonatal Research Network who were enrolled in the myo-inositol trial.
